name: Bananas
portion_guide: A few small slices for dogs. High in sugar so limit portions.
description: Bananas are safe occasional treat high in potassium, vitamins, and fiber. Natural sweetness makes them appealing. High in sugar so give in moderation. Remove peel. Can freeze for summer treat.

name: Strawberries
serving_suggestions: Fresh or frozen, cut into pieces for small dogs
portion_guide: 1-2 strawberries for small dogs, 3-4 for large dogs
description: Strawberries are healthy treat with vitamin C, fiber, and antioxidants. Contain enzyme that helps whiten teeth. Fresh or frozen okay. Remove stems and cut for small pets.

name: Cucumber
portion_guide: A few slices as low-calorie treat
description: Cucumbers are excellent low-calorie treat for weight management. 96% water makes them hydrating. Crunchy texture appeals to many dogs. Can serve with or without peel.

name: Broccoli
caution: Contains isothiocyanates which can cause gastric irritation in large amounts
description: Broccoli is nutritious in small amounts. High in vitamins and fiber. Can be raw or cooked. Limit to under 10% of diet as contains compounds that can irritate stomach in large quantities.

name: Peanut Butter (Xylitol-Free)
serving_suggestions: Use for pill administration, Kong stuffing, training treats
portion_guide: 1 teaspoon for small dogs, 1 tablespoon for large dogs
caution: MUST be xylitol-free. Check labels carefully. High in calories and fat.
description: Peanut butter is beloved treat rich in protein and healthy fats. Perfect for Kongs, pill pockets, or training. CRITICAL: Must verify no xylitol (deadly to dogs). Choose natural, unsalted, no-sugar-added varieties. High calorie so moderate portions.

name: Cooked Salmon
portion_guide: Small pieces as treat or meal topper
caution: MUST be cooked. Raw salmon can carry parasites causing salmon poisoning disease. Remove all bones.
description: Cooked salmon excellent source of omega-3 fatty acids for healthy skin and coat. Must be fully cooked to kill parasites - raw salmon can cause fatal salmon poisoning disease in dogs. Boneless and plain (no salt, butter, seasonings).

name: Plain Oatmeal
serving_suggestions: Cooked plain with water (no milk, sugar, or toppings)
description: Plain cooked oatmeal is fiber-rich, gentle on stomach. Good for dogs with wheat allergies. Must be cooked plain with water - no milk, sugar, artificial sweeteners, or toppings like raisins. Cool before serving.

name: Peas
serving_suggestions: Fresh, frozen, or canned (no salt added)
portion_guide: Small handful as treat or meal addition
description: Peas (green, snow, sugar snap) are nutritious and most dogs enjoy them. Good source of plant-based protein and fiber. Can be fresh, frozen, or canned with no salt. Avoid canned with added sodium.

name: Eggs (Cooked)
serving_suggestions: Scrambled, boiled, or fried without butter/oil
portion_guide: One egg for small dogs, up to two for large dogs
caution: Must be cooked. No raw eggs. No butter, oil, or seasonings.
description: Cooked eggs are excellent protein source with complete amino acids, vitamins, and fatty acids. Scrambled, boiled, or fried plain without butter, oil, salt, or seasonings. Great for coat health. Avoid raw eggs.

name: Spinach
caution: Contains oxalates which can affect calcium absorption. Not recommended for dogs with kidney issues.
description: Spinach is nutrient-dense with vitamins, iron, and antioxidants. Can be raw or cooked. Give in moderation as contains oxalic acid which blocks calcium absorption. Avoid for dogs with kidney problems or history of bladder stones.
